comment.narrative: Effective conservation planning for the Asiatic cheetah is still limited by a lack of detailed basic data on the cheetah itself and on its prey species. There is no detailed biological/ecological knowledge available based on robust statistical methods that is analysed and reported according to scientific standards. There is still no reliable population estimate of the Asiatic cheetah. In addition, many sites still lack comprehensive socio-economic data. Addressing the data and information gaps that is required for effective conservation planning is a long-term and continual endeavor. In the interim, a number of protected areas that are home to cheetah and its prey require sustenance and possibly augmentation of physical protection.

The effectiveness of the game guards are increased
Cheetah, its pray and habitat fauna survived from the drought tension and number of road kills decreased
Applied ecological information collected in order to enhance the future decisions and activities

Develop the local NGOs network and building capacity to take part of the tasks and supports
Organize two workshops for judges on game guard intervention procedures based on judiciary training gaps.
Monitoring of road 44 safety construction project
Assess the impact of water management on the ecology of cheetah and prey in selected areas

 More than 350 individuals were trained on development of Integrated Management Plans for 9 selected wetlands in Iran.  Participatory approach and intersectoral collaboration for planning was introduced and practiced by different stakeholders including GOs, NGOs and the local communities for the first time in 9 different provinces.  In the process of MP development Provincial DoEs were given a new role as facilitators ensuring intersectoral collaboration and providing the opportunity for all stakeholders particularly local communities for their voice to be heard by high level authorities.  CIWP provided support on development of integrated management plans for 8 new wetlands while Esfahan and Fars provincial DoEs voluntarily began development of MPs for Ghav-Khooni and Bakhtegan wetlands with CIWP technical support.  Local governmental and non-governmental stakeholders are fully involved within wetlands management planning processes  PES and Business Planning were introduced by CIWP to provincial DoEs as new tools and mechanisms for wetland management where 6 provinces volunteered to apply them for wetland protected areas in their provinces.  A task force with members from CIWP, MOE and DoE on Sustainable Water Infrastructure has initiated collection, introduction and promotion of international experiences and best practices to improve Dam Management in Iran.  Sustainable livelihood practices are introduced to wetland dependent communities in two pilot site  To reinforce inter-sectoral collaboration and local participation in response to environmental change applying ecosystem approach, CIWP provided technical support to DoE on updating previously developed MPs for Lake Parishan and initiated the process for Lake Urmia and Shadegan Wetland.  NWCSAP was revised and updated by CIWP in collaboration with Habitat Office  CIWP awareness raising campaign on wetland conservation has mobilised public support, participation and contribution in development o

1. Wetland online monitoring mechanism is piloted in Choghakhor. 4. Wetland vulnerability assesment guideline is developed and applied for Iran Ramsar Sites 6- Capacity developed and local committees established around target wetlands to mobilise Omid Fund loans in support of local environmental friendly livelihoods

• An organizational framework facilitating inter-sectoral collaboration among the Government of Japan, UNDP, DoE, CIWP, provincial MoJA and DoE, local Implementing Partners, NGOs and the farmers is fully established at national, provincial and local levels. • Participatory project management, planning and implementation is introduced, practiced and now is applied by different project stakeholders including MoJA, DoE, RWA, Private Sector, Local Communities and the NGOs in all aspects of project implementation. • More than 2000 individuals including local farmers, local experts in both private and the government sectors as well as local NGOs are trained among whom at least 100 resource persons are capable of promoting and supporting project implementation in LU basin. • Public awareness on the role of local communities in establishment of Sustainable Agriculture for Lake Urmia restoration is very well raised to the point where more and more of local farmers are volunteered to join the movement. • Sustainable agriculture is now taken into consideration in national attempts/programmes by MoJA and Lake Urmia Restoration Program in the process of Lake Urmia restoration. • The project has become a practical model of public participation in wetland conservation which has the potential to be up-scaled within the entire LU basin and even other wetlands in Iran.
The project Ended in 2016. A new phase started in 2016.

The HIV/AIDS New funding Model covering period of April 2015 to March 2018 was approved with the title of ‘Enhancement of National HIV Response with Focus on Target Beneficiary Groups in line with the forth National Strategic Plan 2015-2019’. The main objectives of the project are as: • By the end of 2019, at least 90% of the IDUs should use sterilized and non-shared devices for injection in their last injection • 'By the end of 2019, the percentage of VW who have used condom in their latest last sexual contact should reach 20% • 'By the end of 2019, 90% of the estimated pregnant women infected with HIV should be covered by standard treatments in line with prevention of mother-to-child transmission • 'By the end of 2019, more than 90% of the advanced HIV/AIDS infection cases who have started their treatment a year ago, will adhere to treatment

description.narrative: The Office of Board Member is established, staffed and receiving admin support from UNDP.

comment.narrative: Iran takes over as the GF Board Member representing EMR countries.

Improve understanding of the delegation members of technical issue being presented at Board Improve governance and performance of the CCMs across the region Increase awareness and advocacy in the region about the GF work Ensure communication within constituency Ensure proper financial administration and enhancing transparency and responsiveness Increased engagement at governance meetings Ensure efficient operation of the EMRC secretariat

• The delegates gathered in EMRC technical workshop in Sudan, not only strengthened their knowledge and capacity with regard to GF work, but also contributed to developing a regional Position Paper which could guide BM and ABM in decision-making afterwards • Four webinars enhanced the knowledge of participants on Integrated Marketing Communication, Hepatitis C and Population Size Estimation methods, and "Social Mobilization for 3 diseases" which could be used in CCMs' work in the region. • Three research reports published on the subjects of private sector involvement, CCM's performance and OIG audits in the region to help CCMs maximize their contribution to ending the epidemics • Three video-clips were developed that could be used in the region by CCMS/MoHs about the three diseases • Scholarship provided for nominees from CCMs to attend an online training course which will help CCMs better design and use HIV surveillance studies. The EMRC website update was also part of this category which reflects and disseminates EMRC news, opinions and events among the stakeholders in the region. • UNDP provided financial administrative work which is transparent to all stakeholders • Region's delegates in the 35th and 36th Board Meeting contributed to discussions about GF governance and strategic direction as well as promoting regional priorities. • The Communication Focal Point helped establish EMRC communication portfolio and mechanisms for enhanced decision-making support

Ensure communication within constituency Advocacy and Increased engagement at governance meetings Improved understanding by delegation members of technical issue being presented at Board Increase awareness and advocacy in the region about the GF work Ensure proper financial administration and enhancing transparency and responsiveness Ensure efficient operation of the EMRC secretariat

o sustainable ecotourism in KorKamfirouz including build capacity for 20 rural youth as CBO in Mengan Village equip and establish three ecolodge wild watching cottages and handicraft shop and also entertain four groups of visitors

1-MIS system (established) and baseline studies on all sites (undertaken) 2-Gender sensitive MIS system (established) and baseline studies (undertaken) 3-Stocktaking of national INRM policies, programmes, budgets and projects, and PTD , PES and other relevant best practices of relevance to INRM (undertaken) 4-Root Cause analysis of natural resource problems and INRM issues (undertaken) 5-Number of public officials and local community members trained and exposed to INRM issues and best practices, to PTD, to alternative livelihoods etc 6-Number and quality of IEC material developed, disseminated and advocated 7-Number of local community based groups developed 8-Number of assessment and evaluation exercises (undertaken) 9-Studies on CBA, on PES, on PTD, on alternative livelihoods etc (undertaken) 10-PES initiative and pilot (undertaken) 11-PMU established and staff / consultants recruited 12- regular project ME (undertaken) 13-Annual audit

comment.narrative: 1-enhanced MIS system for INRM at FRWO : doesn't exist 2-appropriate gender sensitive MIS system at FRWO : doesn't exist 3-Comprehensive and integrated information of national INRM policies, programmes, budgets and projects, PTD , PES and other relevant best practices of relevance to INRM : does not exist (or is weak) 4-Root causes of natural resource problems and INRM challenges : weak in knowledge and information 5-Extent of knowledge and capacity of public officials and local community on enhanced INRM and best practices in PTD and alternative livelihoods : weak 6-Extent of knowledge products and information available on INRM : insufficient 7-Extent local community based groups are involved in INRM issues : insufficient 8-Baseline information and evaluations of INRM : insufficient 9-Knowledge products on cost-benefits (CBA) of INRM, participatory technology development (PTD) and on alternative livelihoods : insufficient 10-Knowldge products and experience of payment for environmental services (PES) : insignificant and insufficient 11-organisational capacity to implement new development instruments (i.e. a project PMU that can become instituionaly functional at FRWO) : non-existent

1. Developing gender analysis assessment report based on project plan and activities 2. Increasing access to MENARID documentations via website 3. Demonstrating and upscaling MENARID approach on application of solar energy to Islamic Revolution Housing Foundation and renewable energy organization, 3. Involving the government bodies in INRM and engaging them systematically in dialogue on INRM 4. Strengthening enabling environment for INRM, 5. Institutionalizing MENARID exit strategy via strategic plan, 6. Out scaling MENARID approach in other provinces, 7. Raising awareness of all levels stakeholders of the need for and benefits from integrated approaches to natural resources management 8. Receiving community-based demand for INRM 9. Developing new policies, laws, and regulations for INRM 10. Implementing of land use and water management practices

1. An assessment report on gender analysis within plan and activities developed and training workshop held in all pilot areas 2. Key stakeholders informed about their roles and measures through Publication and distribution of 1000 copies of each project newsletters, news on project achievements were published in news agencies, A MENARID documentary was broadcasted by IRIB TV 3. 185 local groups of women and men were established actively involved in INRM sub-project management 4. 5 strategic plans developed. FRWO changed its Watershed Management guideline to Integrated Watershed Management base on what they have learned from MENARID practices. National strategy for INRM implementation in Iran developed based on MENARID approach. 5. Increase in best-practice implementation through 8 innovations including: "breeding livestock", Solar Passive greenhouse", Rain harvesting for rural watershed Park, Optimization of cultivation pattern with medical plants, Solar driers, Integrated participatory Crop Management, Participatory Mapping, 4 PES projects

Settling IWM strategies in place and improving through institutional ownership 4. Replicating of land use and watershed management and women-led businesses in pilot and demonstrated sites 5. Developing INRM, PES and Climate change mitigation/adaptation policies 6. Assessing MENARID achievements to improve climate change resiliency and carbon emission

1. A comprehensive database of the best practices of all pilot sites has developed. 2. A set of comparative study reports in CC, INRM, and PES developed by international consultants 3- The main stakeholders including Ministry of Roads Urban Development, Judicial system, President office of rural development and deprived areas, have communications with MENARID and The MENARID model has been communicated to its own subsidiary organizations. 4. Parliamentarians submitted their replication request as soon as they receiving acquaintance with the achievements 5. One national IWM strategy established at national level in FRWO. 9. IWM national training workshops held including 3 regional workshop for 80 government staffs, 20 meeting for provincial senior governor to institutionalize a MENARID model in country and the MENARID institutional model established in 32 provinces. 10. 185 women-led businesses being developed, these groups could create 501 jobs for women. 11. Climate change and mitigation measures have developed

International Consultant for Ozone Depleting substances (ODSs) Alternative Survey

description.narrative: Implementation of HCFC phase-out Management Plan-Stage-I to reduce ODS and ODPs in Islamic Republic of Iran
capital of a political entity

1. The XIXth Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol in September 2007, through its Decision XIX/6, adopted an accelerated phase-out schedule for HCFCs. The first control is the freeze on production and consumption of HCFCs from 01 January 2013, at the Baseline Level (average of 2009 and 2010 consumption levels). The second control step is the reduction of 10% from the Baseline Levels on 01 January 2015. 2. Preparation of HCFC Phase-out Management Plans (HPMP).

comment.narrative: During the implementation of the CFC phase-out under the Montreal Protocol, HCFCs were approved as interim substitutes for CFCs in many of the projects and activities supported by the MLF. HCFCs, which have an ODP upto 15 % of CFCs are however classified as controlled substances under Annex-C, Group-I of the Montreal Protocol. HCFCs, therefore, have use restrictions and would eventually have to be phased-out. Iran does not produce HCFCs and the domestic demand is entirely met through imports. The total imports of HCFCs in Iran during 2005 were 2,114 metric tonnes. At conservative growth rates, and in the absence of this project, HCFC consumption is projected to reach about 8,293 metric tonnes by 2015.

1. Compliance to the Article 4B of the Montreal Protocol to sustain the ODSs phase-out as well as enforcing strict control of HCFCs consumption 2. Preparation of proposal , submission and approval of HPMP Stage II 3. Compliance to the Article 7 of the Montreal Protocol 4. Raising awareness of the public and private sectors as well as the society on the importance of the ozone layer protection

1. Quota for the year 2017 was specified and allocated to be distributed through licensing and quota system. 5 % reduction of consumption was planned and achieved through quota system. Sustaining phase out activities for controlled substances under the Montreal Protocol was ensured. 2. HPMP Stage II was approved at 77th meeting of the Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund
3. As a key indicator in assessment of the parties’ compliance to the Montreal Protocol’s controlling measures, 2015 country’s Article 7 report and Country Programme data were prepared and timely submitted to the secretariat of the Montreal Protocol and MLF secretariat respectively. 4. International Ozone Day was organized and held in Sep 2016.

1. Compliance with the ultimate HPMP Stage I control target set for 1 Jan 2018 to reduce 30% of the baseline level of HCFCs consumption. 2. Compliance to the Article 7 of the Montreal Protocol 3. Implementation of the approved national survey on the ODSs alternatives 4. Organizing training workshops under stage 1 of HPMP 5. Raising awareness of the public and private sectors as well as the society on the importance of the ozone layer protection

1. T1: Advocacy tour on ecosystem services values (ESV) was held in four pilots in January 2016 with provincial coordination committees and some of local coordination committee members, as well. FRWO managers are now increasingly pointing to the valuable ecosystem services of forests, for example the speeches and interviews of the Forestry Deputy (Dr. Nobakht) usually start with issues and stats related to the ecosystem services of forests, especially water.
T2: Mapping report is finalized (i.e. mapping of ecosystem services in each pilot basi). The ESV report is also finalized, along with a report on PES Options, delivered by int’l consultant. A PES pilot is initiated based on visitor entrance fees from tourists in Baliran, but the mechanism needs improvements.
2. The Green Development Strategy (GDS) addresses the need for linkages to national policies (i.e. NFP, Retreat Policy, Resilience Economy, 6th NDP, and FRWO’s planning procedures). Dialogue with FRWO and Forest High Council has been initiated, to promote changes in regulatory frameworks. Also, a study has been conducted and finalized by the Policy Legislation Consultant, to identify legal and regulatory challenges, and to suggest necessary changes.
3. The Biodiversity Synthesis Report is finalized and animals and plants of high importance are identified in pilot landscapes.
4. SABs candidates – field visits completed and candidate sites report finalised and presented to FRWO TF – provisional approval given to pilot implementation in Gilan pilot. Management options for SABs are also identified and a task force is being formed to work on guidelines, based on international best practices and piloting experience.
5. Meetings and communication with the livestock deputy of MoJA has started and a national consultant is being recruited to closely work with livestock owners and herders in pilot landscapes. Other relevant consultants and stakeholders from related government and pri

1. Public awareness increases 20% overall and 50% in pilot lnadscapes.
2. Forest degradation due to agriculture, illegal cutting and livestock grazing in community pilots decreased by at least 50% in total pilot area and less than non-CFM area.
3. At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping, NTFP enterprise, rural handicrafts, aquaculture, dairy product marketing etc. [to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW] At least 15-20 % increase in income of targeted community groups.
4. At least 2 FMPS reviewed at least 50% of identified actions implemented A compendium of lessons learnt developed
5. Integrated, multi-purpose forestry strategy and plan, including sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

1. Awareness has been rising through reports, media interviews, etc. City NGOs engaged in 3 provinces; fully aware of project goals and being trained.
2. Changing in crop production,(for example change the pattern of cultivation in Chehlchai, and Activating tourism in Doehezar-Sehezar, Farirod and Zilkarod and Baliran, it is anticipated that forest degradation is being decreased.
3. Ecotourism activities with local communities were facilitated by the ecotourism consultant in three pilots and one group is active in Bala bragour and Yoj villages. small businesses are developed and operational in all 4 pilots (handicrafts, recreation, NTFPs, beekeeping etc). One lady from Ghaleghafe Bala, now sells handicrafts on-line. 4 Revolving funds have been initiated in the pilots: Chehelchai (4 women’s groups), Baliran (22 women), 2000/3000 (NGOs and women’s group in Youj).
4. The final drafts of the IMPs for each pilot landscape were finalized in farsi (and Baliran in English) and are ready to be submitted for approval. Discussions were held with IPA on approvals mechanisms, governance and financing, and FRWO was requested to confirm the staffing of LCC Secretariats.
5. The Green Development Strategy for the Hyrcanian Forests (GDS) was finalised in RCC and adjustments were made based on feedback. Discussions were held with IPA on approvals mechanisms, governance and financing, and FRWO was requested to confirm the staffing of GDS Secretariat. It was then revised and amended with collaboration of national-level entities in an expert round table, and is now awaiting approval by Forest High Council

description.narrative: To put in place a collaborative governance system and knowhow for managing a mosaic of land uses in the Caspian Hyrcanian forest that provides habitat integrity and helps maintain landscape level ecosystem functions and resilience
Area of biodiversity setasides created governed by clear specific management guidelines

comment.narrative: Some areas 10 are under biodiversity setasides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation
At least 100000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined with management guidelines

FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected The idea of BD Setasides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area Special Areas for Biodiversity SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity Fauna and Flora A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner Potential sites will be further studied and 100000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid2016 Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest HighCouncil

description.narrative: Extent and quality of forest cover IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative:
Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species
Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 05 loss of forests
No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest Therefore further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1000 square meters Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results

description.narrative: Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: 0 ha
Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across 800000 ha of forests

Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems The study is at the final stages and its expected to suggest amendments to policies laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national Comprehensive Natural Resources Law which is awaiting the final steps in there A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice In addition the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 201620

description.narrative: STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

comment.narrative: SPECIES AND BASELINE TO BE SET IN 2014
NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

No change is expected to be measured in this stage Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer Roe Deer Persian Leopard Wolf Wild Boar and Brown Bear Mammals study is also addressing humanwildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes

description.narrative: An enabling policy and regulatory framework for multiple use forest management is developed
Extent of integration of ecosystem values into production sector strategies and plans

comment.narrative: Ecosystem goods and services are utilised by production sectors however their true ecological value is not understood or incorporated into the economics of key production sectors
Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs

Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called InVest software The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services PES The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant The study will be finalized by Q2 2016 The study has been involving relevant stakeholders mainly Government entities in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values

description.narrative: INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

comment.narrative: Land use plans exist at the basincatchment levels under FRWO management and similar plans exist for DoE management of PAs However a coordinated plan for production sectors does not exist

INTEGRATED MULTIPURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest that a define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b lay out appropriate landuses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

To ensure intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape a so called Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy is under preparation The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015 The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main landuse categories across the whole region The Zoning Plan is also under preparation

description.narrative: INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED National policy and regulatory framework is adjusted to meet BD mainstreaming requirements and is updated within operational procedures

comment.narrative: FRWO and other FMPs are not coordinated and lack inclusion of biodiversity conservation practices

INTERSECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

Local Coordination Committees LCCs have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main intersectoral coordination mechanism at the local level LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans IMPs which ensures functioning of the mechanism Regional Coordination Committee RCC was established as the main driver for intersectoral and interprovincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline Implementation of the Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme The study on policies laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015

description.narrative: Operational guidelines are being utilised to manage multiple land uses in forest landscapes including improved forestry small holder agriculture and livestock practices

comment.narrative: Forestry tourism and agriculture sectors lack a coordinated approach to management
At least 3 improved operational guidelines for i improved forestry ii sustainable small holder agriculture iii improved livestock practices and iv sustainable tourism

As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015 ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization

The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on indepth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes Feasibility of low impact ecotourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months However alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as 5000 during the reporting period In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation One group is developing its skills to do ecotourism activities The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative

description.narrative: Number of community based forest management plans developed AGREED BY COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES and implemented

comment.narrative: 2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30000HA

FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry CF in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances Local communities have been aso exposed to the idea during the reporting period Its expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran In Fariroud Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015

1. functionality of HCFC import consumption monitoring mechanism and licencing system 2. HCFC phase out monitoring mechanism 3. control mechanism over illegal HCFC market

comment.narrative: 1. HCFC import registration mechanism in place

I) Sustaining phase-out of Annex A Group I II, Annex B Group I, II, III and Annex E (in Non-QPS application) of the controlled substances under the Montreal Protocol; II) Having an effective licensing system in place to monitor/control importation of ODSs III) Measure the accurate data on the importation of Methyl Bromide in QPS application IV) Compliance with the National Ozone Committee’s decision to control consumption of HCFCs in relevant industries V) Providing required data on the compliancy to the Montreal Protocol's control measures to enable compliance assessment VI) Raising public, the government stakeholders as well as the civil society’s awareness on the Ozone Layer's issues and importance of the protection activities VII) Compliance with the Montreal Protocol's provisions to prevent increase of consumption of the controlled substances VIII) Making the Halon Physical Bank fully operational to satisfy the needs for recycled Halons IX) Create a databank to include the estimation of the ODSs alternative to be used for the future reporting requirements and providing baseline consumption data X) Facilitating the technology transfer as well as increasing market penetration of the ODSs-free products. Outreaching the information on how to minimize the adverse effects of the UV-radiation XI) Contributing to the global initiative to control and combat the illegal trade of ODSs XII) Timely intervene to solve the technical issues encountered by the converted/equipped beneficiaries XIII) Effective participation in the regional meetings aiming at enhancing coordination and cooperation among parties to meet their commitments toward the Montreal Protocol
